comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: Hi HeyNix, we've got a researcher looking into this one.  The caption on the slide itself is what is printed here (we double checked) but we are tracking this down and will get back.  Thanks for pointing this out. -shelley bernstein, manager of information systems

comment.author: 24940787@N02
comment._content: As a painter born of photographers who has worked as a retoucher (with brushes & ink!!!) there's no doubt in my mind that that's a heavily painted photograph, which was not uncommon in those days (A slightly different -wealthier client- example from the MMA's faboo exhibit in 2000, "La Divine Comtesse," www.metmuseum.org/special/LaDivineComtesse/2.L.htm ). From a historical standpoint, the artist is tricking out the latest/hottest technology as far as it can go, particularly given the venue. & photos were not too great back then, needed a bit of clarification & zipping up. From observation: if a painting, those grays could only be achieved with underpainting; & if underpainting the technique would be more polished.
